data.title: Project MUSE
data.text:
Joseph O. Aimone is a poet who teaches English at Truckee Meadows Community College, Reno, Nevada. His publications include “Millay’s Big Book, or the Female Formalist as Modern,” in Unmanning Modernism and “Undressing Crazy Jane” in Straight with a Twist: Straight Readings: Queer Theory. He received the Humanities Institute University Doctoral Fellowship at the University of California at Davis. He and Olga Rojer are collaborative translators of fiction in Dutch from the Netherlands Antilles.

Frank Martinus Arion, linguist, poet, and novelist, lives in his native Curaçao. His scholarly publications include The Kiss of a Slave: Papiamentu’s West-African Connections. He is the author of several collections of Papiamentu poems, one volume of Dutch poems, and four novels, Dubbelspel, Afscheid van de koningin, Nobele wilden, and De laatste vrijheid. The English translation of Dubbelspel is forthcoming from Faber and Faber Press.

Bernardo Ashetu (1929–1982), born in Suriname, published his collection of poems Yanacuna with an introduction by Cola Debrot in a special issue of Antilliaanse Cahiers. The high quality of his small oeuvre has been recognized only posthumously. Most of his voluminous writing was never published and is now lost.

Fabian A. Badejo, born in Nigeria, has lived in St. Martin since 1981 where he is Editor in Chief of The Guardian. He has been educated at the University of Navarre, Spain, and the University of the West Indies, Jamaica. His poetry has appeared in anthologies in Nigeria, the United Kingdom, and the United States. His publications further include essays on St. Martin and on artists such as Romare Bearden, Roland Richardson, Cynric Griffith, and Ruby Bute. His awards include the St. Martin Man of the Year Award (1997).

Chandra van Binnendijk is the co-author of Twintig jaar beeldende kunst van Suriname 1975–1995 and of Sranan:Cultuur in Suriname (1992). She lives in Paramaribo.

Allison Blakely, born in Clinton, Alabama, is Professor of European and Comparative History at Howard University. He is the author of numerous articles on Russian History and on the European dimensions of the African Diaspora, and published Russia and the Negro: Blacks in Russian History and Thought, for which he received the American Book Award in 1988 from The Before Columbus Foundation, and Blacks in the Dutch World: The Evolution of Racial Imagery in a Modern Society.

Aart G. Broek, born in the Netherlands, has lived in Curaçao since 1981 where he lectures and writes on Antillean literature. He is the author of numerous articles on Papiamentu literature some of which have appeared in the Journal of Caribbean Studies and The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre. He is the author of Something Rich Like Chocolate: Introduction to Caribbean Prose Writing in English and The Rise of a Caribbean Island’s Literature: The Case of Curaçao and Its Writing in Papiamentu. His translations include poetry by Luis Daal, Oda Blinder, Elis Juliana and Pierre A. Lauffer.

Edgar Cairo was born in Suriname. His novels and poetry are deeply influenced by the oral tradition. A prolific author and scholar, he has published ten collections of poems, seven plays, ten novels, two anthologies of essays; in addition, many short stories and essays have appeared in periodicals. His best known novels include Temekoe/Kopzorg, Kollektieve shuld, Adoebe lobi/Alles tegen alles, and Mi boto doro/Droomboot havenloos, Nyumane/In mensennaam. He lives in Amsterdam.

Cándani is the pseudonym of Asha Radjkoemar, born in Suriname. Ghunghru /De rinkelband is gebroken is the first volume of Sarnami poetry published by a poet living in Suriname. Her second volume of poems is Vanwaar je dacht te vertrekken sta je geplant. She lives in the Netherlands.

José Maria Capricorne is an artist born in the artisan quarter of Willemstad in 1932, the son of a carpenter. He has won the 1985 Cola Debrot Prize and was the first to be awarded the Curaçao Museum Lustrum Prize. His works have received serious critical attention in journals, articles, and conferences. He has lived in Brazil, the Netherlands Antilles, where he directed the Curaçao Academy of Art from 1970 until 1988, and in the Netherlands where he now resides.
